column2: Godi Respect controls the proportion of their men and how much tribute that Godis provide to their lord.
The individual Godis do not respect their lord and provide no tribute or men.
The individual Godis have some respect for their chief and provide a paltry tribute and some men.
The individual Godis respect their lord and provide decent tribute and men.
The individual Godis have enormous respect for their lord and provide great tribute and a large number of men.
Vassal Respect controls the proportion of their hird and how much tribute that vassal lords provide to their lord.
The individual Høvdings and Jarls do not respect their liege and provide no tribute or men.
The individual Høvdings and Jarls have some respect for their chief and provide a paltry tribute and some men.
The individual Høvdings and Jarls respect their liege and provide decent tribute and men.
The individual Høvdings and Jarls have enormous respect for their liege and provide great tribute and a large number of men.
Town Respect controls the proportion of their guard and how much tax that towns provide to their lord.
The individual Towns and Cities do not respect their lord and provide no tax nor men.
The individual Towns and Cities have some respect for their chief and provide a paltry tax and some men.
The individual Towns and Cities respect their lord and provides a large tax and men.
The individual Towns and Cities have enormous respect for their lord and provides much tax and a decent sized number of men.

While the Norse hierarchy is rather loose, there is still a dispute over how much authority the King should have... a prestigious king may force through centralization at the cost of upsetting everyone else.
Høvdings and Jarls are able to make their own laws as they always have, with minimal input from whomever is King at the moment.
Nothing has changed among the Høvdings, Godis and Jarls, but the Monarch can now freely take the lands of the followers of other Gods.
The chiefs can no longer wage wars on each other, nor can their lands pass outside the monarch's protection through inheritance.
The lords can now revoke the titles of their lessers, and a more strict hierarchy is appearing with the Monarch at the top.

The monarch now rules a true state... or as much as the monarch can without the aid of a church hierarchy. The monarch can now force the Jarls, Chiefs and Godis to leave their place on the battlefield.
Your respect among the chiefs has increased!
Your respect among the chiefs has decreased!
Your respect among the Godis has increased!
Your respect among the Godis has decreased!
Your respect among the townsfolk has increased!
Your respect among the townsfolk has decreased!
